claim: AI is not the product itself; the experience is the product. AI must be integrated to enhance user value or solve unmet needs. Don't add AI merely for its 'coolness'—use it only when there's a clear reason and a problem that only AI can solve.
rationale: Users care about need fulfillment, not underlying technology. Adding AI without clear user benefit wastes resources and creates complexity. The fundamentals of product management become more important, not less.

claim: AI models operate on probabilities, not certainties. Embrace and manage uncertainty by setting realistic expectations, implementing confidence scores or warnings in interfaces, and designing fallback mechanisms for when predictions fail.
rationale: Unlike deterministic software, AI provides predictions with confidence levels. Users must understand this probabilistic nature. Feedback loops monitor performance and refine interfaces. Trust requires transparency about what AI can and cannot guarantee.

claim: View AI products as continuously evolving systems, not static projects. Plan for long-term maintenance, model retraining, and continuous delivery of updates. User feedback mechanisms are essential to improve future outcomes.
rationale: AI models continuously learn—presenting advantages but also challenges in managing updates and preventing new biases. Model drift degrades performance over time as real-world data changes.

claim: Balance model performance with interpretability. In domains where rationale is critical, balance high-performing 'black-box' models with the demand for explainable decisions using techniques like SHAP and LIME.
rationale: Complex AI models can be opaque, making decisions difficult to understand—problematic in critical contexts like healthcare or finance. Interfaces should provide digestible explanations to build trust.

claim: Determine the line between human and machine decision-making carefully. Design systems that allow for human oversight where necessary (human-in-the-loop), especially in high-stakes environments. Implement fail-safes and escalation protocols.
rationale: Human input is crucial in labeling, interpreting results, and providing real-time feedback—creating an ongoing cycle of improvement.

claim: For AI product-market fit, three pillars must all be strong: business viability, technical feasibility, and user desirability. Weakness in any pillar hinders success.
rationale: A technically feasible, desirable AI that lacks business viability will still fail. Product-market fit requires meeting all three pillars simultaneously.

claim: AI MVPs must deliver tangible benefits immediately, even if AI improves over time. Focus on features providing clear, immediate value. Hardcode aspects to quickly validate concepts without fully optimizing AI models.
rationale: An AI MVP demonstrates potential and provides immediate usable value. Feedback loops illustrate AI's capacity for growth even at early stages.

claim: Use RICE for AI feature prioritization, but add an 'AI investment' parameter and consider data availability/algorithm feasibility as part of confidence.
rationale: AI projects have unique feasibility considerations. Standard RICE must be augmented to capture AI-specific investment and risk factors.

claim: Map AI's capabilities to company mission before integration. Ask: How can AI contribute to goals? Where can AI make a significant difference? Can we sustain ongoing optimization and maintenance?
rationale: AI integration must align with mission, not just technical possibility. Pain points, user impact, and sustainability inform whether AI is the right solution.

claim: Don't use AI if you can't get good data. High-quality data is crucial. If obtaining it is a struggle, consider deterministic alternatives.
rationale: Bias, noise, or irrelevance lead to flawed outputs. Without good data, AI projects are doomed from the start.

claim: Don't use AI if you're not ready for production challenges. Deploying and maintaining AI systems requires significant infrastructure that is often underestimated.
rationale: Without proper infrastructure planning, AI projects fail in deployment even when models work in development.

claim: Don't use AI if you aren't prepared to maintain and iterate indefinitely. AI models require continuous upkeep, data, and infrastructure.
rationale: AI solutions have ongoing operational costs. Treating AI as a one-time project leads to degradation and lost value over time.

claim: Avoid the 'shiny AI object' trap—solving the wrong problem by chasing AI capabilities rather than user needs.
rationale: AI enthusiasm can override user-centric thinking, leading to solutions that don't address real pain points.

claim: AI Product Development Lifecycle: Ideation → Opportunity → Concept/Prototype → Testing/Analysis → Rollout (iterative).
rationale: AI product development moves from business problem to AI solution through iteration. Go/No-Go decisions may send teams back to earlier stages.

claim: Seven AI Superpowers: learning from data, personalization at scale, automating/optimizing workflows, generating new content, prediction/forecasting, real-time adaptation, unlocking new form factors.
rationale: These superpowers map to specific experiences and capabilities. Identifying the right one helps target where AI can enhance or solve needs.

claim: Three AI PM Archetypes: AI Builder PMs, AI Experiences PMs, AI-Enhanced PMs—each with different skill requirements and paths.
rationale: Clarifies roles and needed skills to chart professional development in AI PM.

claim: Build vs. Buy decision factors: core competency, resources/expertise, time to market, long-term strategy, cost, risk tolerance, data privacy, competitive landscape.
rationale: Build offers customization and ownership but requires talent/time. Buy offers speed but creates dependency. Hybrid often balances both.

claim: AI product metric blend: Product Health Metrics + System Health Metrics + AI Proxy Metrics. Success requires measuring across all three.
rationale: A model can be accurate but fail to improve engagement; a system can be fast but wrong. Comprehensive measurement reveals true product health.

claim: Fine-tuning vs. RAG vs. Grounding: choose based on need for accuracy, freshness, or rapid iteration.
rationale: Each method has different trade-offs. Select based on whether you need specialized accuracy, dynamic relevance, or quick adjustments.

claim: AI agent success metrics: task completion rate, accuracy/quality, intervention frequency, user satisfaction.
rationale: These metrics distinguish truly autonomous agents from glorified chatbots—tracking success and reduced human oversight.

claim: Spotify's AI DJ: personalization at scale creates unique, adaptive experiences reflecting individual and group dynamics.
rationale: Shows personalization superpower translating to a specific feature with real-time adaptation.

claim: Google Maps feedback loop: users provide real-time feedback that improves future outcomes, countering model drift.
rationale: Demonstrates continuous improvement through user feedback; the product gets better through use.

claim: Waymo's SimulationCity: synthetic data for rare or dangerous scenarios, then incorporate real data.
rationale: Shows appropriate use of synthetic data for safety-critical, scarce scenarios while anchoring to real data.
